frameDefinitions: The words in this frame describe the manipulation of an Entity by an Agent.
An Agent causes an Impactor to make sudden, forcible contact with an Impactee, or manipulates two (or more)
An Agent manipulates an Instrument in order to achieve a Purpose.

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
An Agent ceases an Activity without completing it. '' 'After the lawsuit, the company stopped producing the once very profitable toy.'
frameExamples: He <t>slammed</t> his fist down on the table and bellowed something unintelligible.
For cold conditions, we recommend that you <t>use</t> a heat gun or a hair dryer to make the adhesive work better.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
After the lawsuit, the company <t>stopped</t> producing the once very profitable toy.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  <fen>Agent</fen> is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs:
The <fen>Entity</fen> being manipulated often occurs as the direct object of verbs:

The part of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s body being used to manipulate the <fen>Entity</fen> may also be expressed. While the default is for an <fen>Agent</fen> to use his/her hands, other body parts may be specified. This frame element usually occurs as a PP-complement.
When the manipulation takes place
The spatial setting in which the manipulation takes place.
The <fen>Impactee</fen> is the entity which is hit by the <fen>Impactor</fen>.
The <fen>Impactor</fen> is the entity that hits the <fen>Impactee</fen> because of the <fen>Agent</fen>'s efforts.
The <fen>Impactors</fen> are the multiple entities that collide.
The <fen>Agent</fen>  causes an impact.

The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, 
typically non-human, force that causes an <fen>Impactor</fen> to make sudden, 
forcible contact with an Impactee.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen>  when the impact occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The Agent uses the Instrument to achieve their Purpose.
This role identifies the purpose for which an Agent uses the Instrument.
An entity directed by the <fen>Agent</fen> that serves to bring about the <fen>Purpose</fen> of the <fen>Agent</fen>.
An <fen>Instrument</fen> that has a function associated with it.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> uses the <fen>Instrument</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the Agent uses the Instrument.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies <fen>Agent</fen> that stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Activity</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> stops.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> stops the <fen>Activity</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>A robot arm</fex> grasps the box on the conveyor belt and seals it.
Squeeze <fex>the ball</fex> as many times as you can.
Kim grasped the needle <fex>between finger and thumb</fex>.
I seized the letter <fex>before he did</fex>.
<fex>In the hallway</fex> he managed to grabthe monarch by the ankles
What I want to know is who smacked <fex>my head</fex> with a 10-ton truck?
Those hoodlums strike my car <fex>with water balloons</fex> every day!
Mr. Addams likes to collide <fex>toy trains</fex> at high speed.
<fex>One juggler</fex> was hitting the ceiling with every other ball.
<fex>A violent explosion</fex>rattled the windows.
A postman rammed his Fiat Panda into a getaway car <fex>after spotting the burglars </fex> .
Father Shanahan , of Rushey Mead , Leicester , rammed his Datsun into another car <fex>on the way to the city 's Gilroes cemetery</fex>.
For cold conditions, we recommend using <fex>a heat gun or a hair dryer</fex> to make the adhesive work better.
Mirabella shared the mischievous vision of childlike exuberance and used the chair <fex>as a pseudo jungle gym</fex>.
I went and used that ball <fex>yesterday</fex> and i bowled 5 games and i left about 14 ten pins with it.
<fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
